EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

INTRODUCTION

TradeMark Nitrogen, Corp.  (TradeMark) is a producer of nitrogen-based fluid products located at 1216 Old Hopewell Road in Tampa, Florida.  An integral component of the manufacture of these products is anhydrous ammonia.  The anhydrous ammonia storage capacity of the facility, after administrative controls, is approximately 388,000 pounds.  This inventory exceeds the 10,000-pound threshold for anhydrous ammonia set by EPA under the Risk Management Program (RMP) Rule codified at 40 CFR 68.  Pursuant to the requirements of the rule, TradeMark has prepared this Risk Management Program (RMP) Plan. We are proud of our environmental, health, and safety efforts and programs and our record in these areas.  The following sections outline our RMP plan.   

OVERALL RESPONSIBILITY

Our Technical Manager and Safety and Worker Protection Manager serve as the facility's RMP and PSM Coordinators, respectively.  Together, these individuals share the overall responsibility for ensuring that our facility operates in a safe and reliable manner.  This responsibility includes overseeing the implementation of the elements of our risk management program.  To ensure that our risk management program is appropriately developed and implemented, our President has assigned the role of RMP Coordinator to the Technical Manager, a staff member with the necessary background, training, and experience.  The RMP Coordinator, acting with the authority delegated directly from the President, has the responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the EPA RMP elements.  In addition, the RMP Coordinator works closely with the Safety and Worker Protection Manager to integrate the elements of OSHA's PSM program (where applicable) as required under Section 68.15 of the RMP rule.  

The RMP Coordinator serves as the chairman of the facility's RMP Steering Committee.  This committee comprises members with responsibilities for developing and managing specifi

c elements of our risk management and process safety programs.  The members of this committee are assigned by the President based on recommendations from the RMP Coordinator.  Currently, the members of the RMP Steering Committee include the following: 

 *  RMP Coordinator (Technical Manager)
 *  PSM Coordinator (Safety and Worker Protection Manager)
 *  Production Manager
 *  Employee Representative(s)

The following sections identify the specific responsibilities for each aspect of our risk management and process safety management programs.

HAZARD ASSESSMENTS

The Technical Manager has the responsibility for (1) ensuring that offsite consequence analyses for each regulated process are consistently performed and documented in accordance with Sections 68.20 through 68.39 and (2) selecting the scenarios that will be reported in the facility Risk Management Program Plan as required under Section 68.165. The Technical Manager also is responsible for ensuring that the accident history for each covered process is appropriately documented and maintained in accordance with Section 68.42 and 68.168 of the RMP rule.

The rule requires the evaluation of a worst case scenario, even though the likelihood of the occurrence of such a scenario may be extremely small.  The worst case scenario has been defined as a catastrophic release of the entire anhydrous ammonia inventory, 71,200 pounds, from Tank 601.  The distance to the toxic endpoint as predicted by the USAF Toxic Chemical Dispersion Model is 0.62 miles.  In addition to the worst case scenario, an alternative release scenario has been modeled employing more appropriate meteorological conditions and release assumptions.  In the alternative release scenario, 10 pounds of anhydrous ammonia per minute are assumed to be released from the lifting of a pressure relief valve.  A ten-minute release would be expected in such a scenario.  Based upon these assumptions, the distance to the endpoint as predicted by the same model employ

ed above is approximately 0.05 miles (264 feet).  At this distance, no impact on public receptors would be anticipated.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

TradeMark has had no reportable releases of anhydrous ammonia from the process since the commencement of operations at the Old Hopewell Road facility in 1983.  We have always taken a pro-active stance in the safety of our employees and the surrounding community and environment.

PREVENTION PROGRAMS

The RMP and PSM Coordinators have the responsibility for ensuring that the facility has an integrated, effective, and compliant prevention program that meets EPA RMP (Sections 68.65 through 68.87 of the RMP rule) and OSHA PSM requirements.  Although the Coordinators have many specific individual responsibilities, some of the responsibilities for specific program elements are assigned to other members of the PSM and RMP Steering Committees (as listed in the following sections).

PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION

The responsibility for process safety information (PSI) (Section 68.65 of the RMP rule) is divided between two individuals.  The Technical Manager has responsibility for process chemical and equipment information while the Production Manager has responsibility for process technology information.  The RMP Coordinator has the responsibility of ensuring that all of this information is readily accessible for use.

PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS

In accordance with Section 68.67 of the RMP rule, the RMP Coordinator has the responsibility for ensuring that process hazard analyses (PHAs) are scheduled, conducted, and documented by trained personnel for all regulated processes.  The PSM and RMP Coordinators identify candidate PHA team leaders from within the facility and ensure that they receive appropriate training before leading PHAs.  The Coordinators may also use outside contractors to lead PHAs when appropriate.  The other members of the RMP Steering Committee are responsible for (1) ensuring that the information and personnel necess

ary to conduct PHAs are available according to the PHA implementation schedule and (2) resolving recommendations that are assigned to their respective areas.

OPERATING PROCEDURES

In accordance with Section 68.69 of the RMP rule, the Production Manager has the responsibility for ensuring that complete and accurate operating procedures are in place for all regulated processes.  The Production Manager works closely with the Technical Manager and the Safety and Worker Protection Manager to develop and maintain the facility's safe work practices.

TRAINING

In accordance with Section 68.71 of the RMP rule, the Production Manager has the responsibility for (1) ensuring that operations employees receive and understand training applicable to their specific jobs and the associated processes and (2) documenting the training.  The Safety and Worker Protection Manager and the Technical Manager have the responsibility for (1) ensuring that all facility employees receive and understand training in safe work practices applicable to their jobs and (2) documenting the training.
 
MECHANICAL INTEGRITY

In accordance with Section 68.73 of the RMP rule, the Technical Manager has the responsibility for the overall mechanical integrity program, with specific emphasis on written procedures, maintenance training, the equipment and instrumentation inspection/test program and documentation, and equipment deficiency resolution.  TradeMark also employs outside contractors and/or consultants to assist in the implementation and maintenance of the mechanical integrity program.  The Technical Manager works with the appropriate maintenance personnel to define and maintain appropriate quality assurance procedures for all types of equipment acquisitions/installations/repairs.

MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE

In accordance with Section 68.75 of the RMP rule, the RMP and PSM Coordinators have the responsibility for the overall management of change (MOC) program; however, the Production Manager has responsibili

ty for ensuring that the overall MOC program is effectively implemented.

PRE-STARTUP REVIEW

In accordance with Section 68.77 of the RMP rule, the PSM and RMP Coordinators have the responsibility for the overall pre-startup review program, which is closely related to the MOC program. However, the Production Manager has the primary responsibility for ensuring that this program is effectively implemented before affected operations begin.

COMPLIANCE AUDITS

In accordance with Section 68.79 of the RMP rule, the PSM and RMP Coordinators have the responsibility for ensuring that compliance audits regularly occur (and are documented) to verify that the prevention program is working and meets EPA/OSHA requirements.  Each member of the PSM and RMP Steering Committees has responsibility for resolving any identified deficiency in his or her area.

INCIDENT INVESTIGATION

In accordance with Section 68.81 of the RMP rule, the Technical Manager has the responsibility for designing and managing the incident investigation program, including tracking resolution of investigation findings and recommendations.  The Technical Manager also has the responsibility of ensuring that only trained personnel lead our investigations.  The Technical and Production Managers each have responsibility for ensuring that all incidents are reported and investigated, and the investigations findings are resolved, documented, and communicated to affected personnel.

EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION

In accordance with Section 68.83 of the RMP rule, the PSM and RMP Coordinators, working with employee representatives on the PSM and RMP Steering Committee, have the responsibility of involving employees in the planning and implementation of the facility's prevention program elements.



HOT WORK PERMITS

In accordance with Section 68.85 of the RMP rule, the PSM and RMP Coordinators have the responsibility of developing and maintaining the facility's hot work permit program.

CONTRACTORS

In accordance with Section 68.

87 of the RMP rule, the Technical Manager has the overall responsibility for the contractor program; however, the Production Manager is responsible for ensuring that the requirements of the program are implemented in his area of responsibility.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

In accordance with Sections 68.90 and 68.95 of the RMP rule, the Technical Manager is responsible for (1) designing, implementing, and maintaining the facility's emergency response plan, (2) ensuring that all associated training is conducted and documented as necessary, (3) coordinating the site emergency response plan with the community emergency response plan, and (4) responding to local emergency planners/responders when questions arise.  TradeMark employees would not respond in the unlikely event of an emergency release.  Personnel are trained to immediately notify the appropriate facility managers.  Although TradeMark employees would not actively participate in emergency response activities, they would be available to assist appropriately trained personnel in other critical aspects of the emergency response.  In such a situation, TradeMark employees may be called upon to provide details on the processes, equipment locations, and/or other facility-specific details that may be integral to emergency response activities. 
 
RMPLAN PREPARATION AND SUBMISSION

The RMP Coordinator is responsible for preparing and submitting the Risk Management Program Plan for the facility (after review and approval by the President) as required under Sections 68.150 through 68.185 of the RMP rule.

RMPLAN COMMUNICATION

The President and the Technical Manager have the responsibility of providing Risk Management Program Plan information (other than the required EPA submission) to employees and the public as required under Section 68.210 of the RMP rule.
